column1: Marshfield is a city in Wood County and Marathon County in the U.S. state of Wisconsin. It is located at the intersection of U.S. Highway 10
column2: Highway 13 and Highway 97. The largest city in Wood County
column7: and 900 were in Marathon County. The city is part of the United States Census Bureau's Marshfield-Wisconsin Rapids Micropolitan Statistical Area
column8: which includes all of Wood County (2010 population: 74
column9: 749). The portion of the city in Marathon County is part of the Wausau Metropolitan Statistical Area.

column3: surveyors working for the U.S. government marked all the section corners in the 6 by 6 miles (9.7 by 9.7 km) square which now includes Marshfield

column1: This Township is nearly all Dry land
column2: There being no Swamp of consequence in it. There being to much clay & rocks in it. Particularly that part which contains Fir & Hemlock. The surface is rough & uneven(?) and rather to flat for anything but meadow. There is some good Pine it but to much scattering to make it an object. The Township is well watered with small streams but none of them are of sufficient size for Milling purposes. The streams are lined with Alder & many of them producing good hay. There are no improvements in this Township.

column1: Marshfield was settled much later than many surrounding towns. DuBay started his trading post 40 miles (64 km) east on the Wisconsin River around 1818. A sawmill was built at Nekoosa in 1832. A sawmill was built at Neillsville around 1847. The first building at Marshfield came in 1872.In 1872 the Wisconsin Central Railway was building the leg of its line from Stevens Point through the forest to what would become Colby
column2: heading north for Lake Superior. The railway needed a supply depot between those two towns
column3: and Marshfield was about midway. At the railroad's request
column6: and his brother Frank came to the area and started cutting an opening in the forest. They built a two-room log hotel at what is now the corner of Depot and Chestnut streets
column7: with bunks in the west room and tables
column9: bar and store in the east room. That crude building between the stumps was the first permanent structure in Marshfield.Marshfield's name is explained two ways. It might have been named for John J. Marsh
column10: one of the original owners of land in the area. Marshfield might also have been named after Marshfield
column12: since the Wisconsin Central Railway was financed with money from Massachusetts and other stops along the WC's line were named after towns in Massachusetts

column15: a "Yankee" migrant of English descent from Massachusetts and later governor of Wisconsin
column16: built a sawmill near the railway
column17: with a millpond. By 1885 he had added a general store
column19: a furniture factory and a flour and feed mill. Other businesses started
column26: and a milliner. There were also churches and schools. The city was incorporated in 1883.  By 1885 the population exceeded 2

column1: The late 1800s saw a burst of railroad building. In 1872 the Wisconsin Central built the first line through town. In 1887 Upham Manufacturing started a line south from town to haul logs from Cameron and Richfield. In 1890 a line to Neillsville was built. In 1891 a line was built from Centralia (now Wisconsin Rapids)
column3: and a third from Wausau to Marshfield came from the north. In 1901 a second line was built from Wisconsin Rapids to Marshfield. In 1903 38 passenger trains stopped daily in Marshfield.  So many tracks intersected in the community that Marshfield was nicknamed "Hub City".

column1: The hub was also agricultural.  Dairying began to organize as cheese factories started up
column2: such as the one at Nasonville in 1885.  Roddis and then Blum Brothers made wooden cheese boxes in Marshfield. By 1921 the Blum plant was making 3
column3: 500 boxes a day. In 1907 the first cold storage plant was built in town
column4: to store local cheese before shipping it by rail to larger markets.  Ice cream factories followed
column7: and liquid milk. In 1923 a spokesman for the Soo Line Railroad said that Marshfield shipped more dairy products than any other city in the United States.St. Joseph's hospital began with six beds in 1890. Operated by the Sisters of the Sorrowful Mother
column8: it offered early health insurance.  Lumbermen could pay a flat rate
column9: and in exchange St. Joseph's would care for them in case of injury. In 1916
column10: six local doctors formed a group practice clinic in the second story of the Thiel building downtown
column11: calling themselves Marshfield Clinic.German immigrants made up two thirds of Marshfield's population in the 1890s. One of the two early newspapers
column13: was published in German.  Many had family back in Germany as World War I approached

column1: The University of Wisconsin–Stevens Point at Marshfield and Mid-State Technical College –  Marshfield Campus are located in Marshfield.

column1: The Marshfield Clinic system provides health care for much of northern Wisconsin. It operates residency programs in dermatology
column7: as well as a transitional year of residency. In addition
column8: fellowships are offered in internal medicine and palliative medicine. The Marshfield Clinic also hosts medical and physician assistant students for the University of Wisconsin School of Medicine and Public Health and provides medical education
